Text: merits of the several districts. The par-

Text: liamentary tours of inspection have been

Text: member for Macquarie as mere picnicing

Text: excursions, and the right honorable mem-

Text: most reprehensible way of the " drawing of

Speaker: NA
Text: corks" which, he suggests, took place on these

Text: Federal Capital. One does not need the

Speaker: NA
Text: did not possess - the characteristics es-

Speaker: NA
Text: sential ^to a Federal city. I recognised that

Speaker: NA
Text: Tumut" would be subject to dense fogs in

Text: winter, and that in the summer months the

Speaker: NA
Text: atmosphere would be humid-climati c con-

Text: ditions that should not be associated with

Text: the Federal Capital. The water supply,

Text: however, would certainly be sufficient f o r

Text: said in connexion with some o f the

Text: almost able to calculate for myself

Text: what would be the volume available for the

Text: Capital i f it were established there. I was

Text: convinced, however, that the climatic con-

Text: ditions would not be conducive to the health

Text: ceedingly circumscribed. I drew a mental

Text: matic conditions were distinctly supe-

Text: at Lyndhurst, where a supply would have to

Text: be gathered from all parts of the district

Text: and conveyed in channels or tunnels to the

Text: sufficient, not merely for domestic require-

Text: ments, but to provide the necessary power

Text: for other purposes. I n three respects

Text: -namely , climatic conditions, purity of

Speaker: NA
Text: water supply, and water power available,

Text: I found that Batlow was all that

Speaker: NA
Text: could be desired: nevertheless, it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not contain all the requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: of a Federal Capital site. I n the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: this pleasure trip-becaus e it was a plea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure, notwithstanding the discomforts of tra-

Text: velling, to know that one was doing his duty

Text: to his country in inspecting these sites-w e

Speaker: NA
Text: visited Lyndhurst. I was in no way pre-

Text: judiced against that site, but went there

Text: determined to do it f u l l justice. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: we inspected it in the month of May, the

Speaker: NA
Text: road along which we travelled for some

Speaker: NA
Text: miles was a very dusty one. I do not wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to question the veracity of those who sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port the selection of this site, but we know

Speaker: NA
Text: that a man who is enthusiastically in favour

Speaker: NA
Text: of a particular district is not the best per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son from whom to obtain reliable informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in regard to it. Such men are prone, not

Speaker: NA
Text: -wilfully, but unwittingly, to supply infor-

Text: mation that is not reliable. They look

Speaker: NA
Text: only at the bright side of the picture, and

Text: one must therefore discount their evidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been told of the remarkable pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductiveness of the land in the neighbour-

Speaker: NA
Text: hood of Lyndhurst, and I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to mention that during my visit I

Speaker: NA
Text: made inquiries on the subject. I know good

Speaker: NA
Text: country when I see it. The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Macquarie thinks that because he

Speaker: NA
Text: was reared among pumpkins he should be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as an exceptionally good authority

Speaker: NA
Text: on farming. I was born and reared in a

Speaker: NA
Text: district in the old country where scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: farming, is practised, and where the occupa-

Speaker: NA
Text: . tions of the farmers comprise something

Speaker: NA
Text: more substantial that the growing of pump-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins and the rearing of pigs, so that I

Speaker: NA
Text: should have some knowledge of agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. I therefore resent the suggestion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Macquarie that,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he was born in the Lyndhurst dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trict, he should be better qualified to judge

Speaker: NA
Text: of the productive character of the country

Speaker: NA
Text: than is any other honorable member. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my youth I had an intimate experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture in a district where rotation of

Speaker: NA
Text: crops was practised, and where one saw

Text: truly scientific farming. I have represented

Speaker: NA
Text: a pastoral district for some years, and pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sume that I should not have been returned

Speaker: NA
Text: to represent the interests of the people there

Speaker: NA
Text: i f I were incapable of properly voicing

Speaker: NA
Text: their aspirations and interests. I may

Speaker: NA
Text: also mention that I have travelled all over

Speaker: NA
Text: the western district, and should therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: have some knowledge of its characteristics.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the Lyndhurst district we find undulat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing country, practically rolling downs, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is certainly not good agricultural land. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am strengthened in that view by the

Speaker: NA
Text: opinions of those who lived in this district

Speaker: NA
Text: some years ago. I sought information, not

Speaker: NA
Text: from those who were specially interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: the selection of Lyndhurst, but from a

Speaker: NA
Text: source which I knew would be untainted by

Speaker: NA
Text: personal considerations. We have been told

Speaker: NA
Text: that yields of 60 Bushels of wheat to the

Speaker: NA
Text: acre are obtainable there, but men who at

Speaker: NA
Text: one time carried on agricultural operations

Speaker: NA
Text: in the district informed me that in reallv

Text: good seasons theyhad secured as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 bushels to the acre, but that as a rule

Speaker: NA
Text: the return obtained by them was not suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient to pay for the labour of ploughing,

Speaker: NA
Text: sowing, and harvesting, and to cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of selling. That is good evidence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the agricultural possibilities of the dis-

Text: trict. The fact that, although it is within

Speaker: NA
Text: easy distance of Sydney, and is connected,

Speaker: NA
Text: by rail with that centre of distribution, land

Speaker: NA
Text: in the district is devoted, not to agriculture,

Text: but to pastoral purposes, should be a suffi-

Text: cient answer to those who claim that such

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent yields can be obtained from

Speaker: NA
Text: it. We saw paddocks which at one time

Speaker: NA
Text: had been under the plough, but had since

Speaker: NA
Text: been turned into sheep runs. As a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of fact, the land there will carry about two

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep to five acres.

Text: Th e honorable member

Text: has destroyed the Opposition; they have

Text: all left the Chamber.

Text: I care not whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they are present or absent. I am speaking,

Text: not merely to honorable members, but to

Text: the people of Australia. I am responsible

Text: to my constituents only, and I intend to

Text: give adequate expression to my views. The

Text: Lyndhurst district consists of what is ad-

Text: mittedly pastoral country, and i t is de-

Text: cidedly uninteresting. We found a

Text: monotonous sameness about it-a n utter

Text: want of picturesqueness. Here and there

Text: we saw little knolls, and a line of moun-

Text: tains was dimly visible in the distance,

Text: qualifications of the site did not take me

Text: water. Had it not been for the fact that

Text: provided us with something to drink,

Text: we should have been very thirsty

Text: left, and went over the Canobolas

Speaker: NA
Text: site. I had seen the Bathurst site the

Text: morning before, and I could not understand

Text: for the life of me why honorable members

Text: representing the district should go back

Text: upon those eligible sites in f avour of Lynd-

Text: hurst. When I inspected the Canobolas

Text: site I found' that it was picturesque, that

Text: there was good rich agricultural land there,

Text: and that the Lyndhurst site could not be

Speaker: NA
Text: compared to it. The Bathurst site also is

Text: miles ahead of the Lyndhurst site in suit-

Text: ability for a Federal Capital. I must ad-

Text: mit that there is some doubt about the

Speaker: NA
Text: the information I received. I understoood

Text: that the water supply at Orange was near

Text: and the people were put on short rations

Text: Some people wish to know why, as a New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Welshman, I do not advocate the site

Text: which comes nearest to the zoo-miles limit

Text: from Sydney. Some' politicians may be

Text: stand-point. But in this matter I shall be

Text: guided first, not by what some per-

Text: sons may consider to be my duty

Text: to my own State, but by what I

Speaker: NA
Text: consider to be my duty to the - Common-

Text: wealth. I f any man in New South Wales

Text: tells me that, as a Federal member, I

Text: should be parochial on this question, I

Speaker: NA

Text: to press domination, or the commands of

Text: certain New South Wales members, in

Text: dealing with this question. I drove over

Text: the Canobolas site, and i f I had to give a

Text: vote for a site in the western district, I

Speaker: NA

Text: visit the sites in his district. I may say

Text: that I was greatly impressed by the sites

Text: which we visited in the Monaro country.

Text: The land is possibly no better agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: land than that at theLyndhurst site; but

Speaker: NA
Text: from the evidence of my own senses, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was satisfied that with mountains, snow-

Speaker: NA
Text: falls, and adjacent rivers, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: an ample supply of the purest water. It

Text: is quite unnecessary that any man should

Speaker: NA
Text: be called to the Bar of the House to cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: roborate or verify a report, to that effect

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the Monaro sites. There is ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously room for doubt about the existence

Speaker: NA
Text: of a very important factor i f it is neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary that an expert should be brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bar of this House to say that it is pos-

Text: sible to provide a water supply at anv

Speaker: NA
Text: given site. That, to my mind, is an indi-

Text: cation of absolute weakness in the claims

Speaker: NA
Text: of that particular-site. No expert engineers'

Speaker: NA
Text: reports are required to prove to any man

Speaker: NA
Text: visiting the Monaro sites that an ample and

Text: purpose we have in view. I t must not

Text: to be pumped at that site, and that that

Text: Tha t cost would

Speaker: NA
Text: not pay the interest on the cost of provid-

Text: ing a water supplv for Lyndhurst.

Text: I am prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: admit that. I f we required water power,

Text: as 'well as an ordinary water supply for the

Text: inhabitants of the Federal Capital, the

Text: cost at Bombala would be consider-

Text: able. The first feature to be looked for in

Text: must know the source of the supply, the

Text: city of 50,000 inhabitants could be secured

Text: at Bombala at a medium cost, but that

Text: does not meet all that I think necessary.

Text: I should like to have water power provided

Text: if it could be supplied economically.

Text: Although the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Eden-Monaro diligently explained the

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages of the sites in his elec-

Text: torate, I could quite realize that at

Text: Bombala we should be likelv to suffer to

Text: some extent from biting winds in the win-

Text: ter time. Climate is, of course, one of the

Text: features which must be considered in con-

Text: nexion with these sites, and there are

Text: varying degrees of climate, - which

Speaker: NA
Text: must 'be compared. We must take

Text: all the essential features of a site

Text: I admit that Bombala presented some ele-

Text: ments which were not presented by sites I

Text: had previously visited. We drove out some

Text: ten miles from Bombala in order to obtain

Text: some knowledge as to whence the Capital,

Text: if established at that site, would draw its

Text: food supply. I was perfectly satisfied with

Speaker: NA
Text: the land that I saw. The area was some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what circumscribed, but the land was. really

Text: good agricultural land. I t is not at present

Speaker: NA
Text: utilized to any extent, because it is too far

Text: from a market. When, in dealing with the

Text: agricultural possibilities of various sites, the

Text: honorable member for Macquarie submitted

Text: a comparison of the areas under cultivation

Text: distance from a market has prevented agri-

Text: cultural development at many of the sug-

Text: land in the neighbourhood of the Tooma

Text: site could not be profitably used, except for

Text: the growth of fodder, to meet times of

Text: freight upon that produce to the mar-

Text: without fear of contradiction, that i f

Text: the Eden-Monaro district had a rail-

Text: way, by which the people there could

Text: get their produce expeditiously to market,

Text: the percentage of land under cultivation in

Text: that district would exceed the percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honorable member for Macquarie

Text: quoted for the district around Lyndhurst.

Text: part in municipal affairs, and who has

Text: studied the question in the newer suburbs

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales, where the initiatory

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties of a sewerage system have had to

Speaker: NA
Text: be faced, I am naturally interested in
